Dear Michelle Seigo:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on April 3, 2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation
• (4) An agency shall document placement
specifications consistent with the information
contained in the reevaluation. The placement
specifications must include all the following:
• (a) The age, number, SOGIE, race, ethnic
background, and characteristics of
children preferred by the applicants.
Two of three foster home files reviewed did not document preferred placement
specifications regarding SOGIE.
CPA Rule 400.12415 Unusual incident reporting policy
• (1) An agency must adhere to the following
incident reporting protocols:
• (a) Immediately notify the child's parents;
the department licensing authority; the
lawyer guardian ad litem and court, as
applicable; the department; and the foster

child's parents, if any of the following
occurs:
• (iv) Any medical and mental illness
or condition that results in
treatment at a hospital emergency
room or inpatient hospitalization of
a foster child.
Two of six foster care files reviewed and one of two independent living files
reviewed did not have documentation that an incident report was completed when
a foster youth went to the emergency room.
CPA Rule 400.12422 Foster care case record
• (3) The record must contain all the following
information:
• (g) A photograph taken at least annually.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not have a youth's picture updated
annually as required.
CPA Rule 400.12502 Program statement
• (2) An agency shall give a copy of the program
statement to a youth before placement in
independent living.
One of two independent living files reviewed did not have documentation the
agency provided the youth with IL program statement.
CPA Rule 400.12503 Policy and procedures
• (3) An agency shall provide a youth in
independent living with a copy of the agency's
policies and procedures required by this rule.
One of two independent living files reviewed did not have documentation the
agency provided the youth with IL policies and procedures.

CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living agreement
• (2) The agreement must be signed and dated by
the youth and the social service worker. The
agreement must be reviewed with the youth at
least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
Two of two independent living files reviewed did not have documentation the
independent living contract was updated and provided to youth every 90 calendar
days as required.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Agency will be sure to promptly address and document any safety concerns
and action taken.
• In situations where a safety plan is needed it must be completed in writing
and uploaded.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• There was no consultation requested or required.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were 1 incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period. Special evaluation 2025SEC0000038 was initiated on 10/14/2025 regarding
allegations a licensed foster parent was utilizing corporal punishment as discipline.

The licensed foster parent was found to be in violation of licensing rules and agency
policy. Revocation of the foster home license was initiated and is currently pending.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The
agency’s interim inspection was completed on 5/14/2024 and the CAP was
approved on 8/7/2024. The agency was cited for 6 violations, 1 of which was
repeated this year. Of the 1 repeat, there was a slight increase in individual
incidents of non-compliance. In 2023, 7 violations were established, 1 of which
was repeated this year. The agency will need to establish additional corrective
planning for the repeated violation to ensure a reduction of incidents.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator assessment was received and reviewed. The assessment
noted the agency struggled at times with challenging cases and locating
appropriate placements for youth displaying severe behaviors. However, the CA
noted the previous year CAP was largely effective. The process of development the
CAP together with staff and utilizing the checklist was effective. In addition, the
agency has held regularly scheduled quarterly meetings regarding the CAP
throughout the review period that has also been helpful. The assessment noted the
agency will continue working on areas of follow through but have seen improvement
and the CA believes the agency will continue to improve.
Financial Overview
Not applicable.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff interviews were conducted with two staff via telephone. Staff reported feeling
supported by the agency. Supervisors and coworkers are available to assist as
needed. Staff did not report any concerns but did express it would be helpful for
new workers to have more guidance on where documents should be uploaded.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care and licensing services. All files were stored securely and
there is a cross shredder for CHRI.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
